current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text: To delay the implementation of certain provisions of the Biggert-Waters Flood Insurance Reform Act of 2012 and to reform the National Association of Registered Agents and Brokers, and for other purposes.

toc-entry.#text: TITLE I—Homeowner Flood Insurance Affordability Act
Sec. 103. Delayed implementation of flood insurance rate increases; draft affordability framework.
Sec. 106. Funds to reimburse homeowners for successful map appeals.
Sec. 108. Treatment of floodproofed residential basements.

TITLE II—National Association of Registered Agents and Brokers
Sec. 202. Reestablishment of the National Association of Registered Agents and Brokers.

text.#text: The duties and responsibilities of the
educate property owners and policyholders under the National Flood Insurance Program on—
individual flood risks;
flood mitigation;
measures to reduce flood insurance rates through effective mitigation; and
the flood insurance rate map review and amendment process;

assist policy holders under the National Flood Insurance Program and property owners to understand the procedural requirements related to appealing preliminary flood insurance rate maps and implementing measures to mitigate evolving flood risks;
assist in the development of regional capacity to respond to individual constituent concerns about flood insurance rate map amendments and revisions;
coordinate outreach and education with local officials and community leaders in areas impacted by proposed flood insurance rate map amendments and revisions; and

aid potential policy holders under the National Flood Insurance Program in obtaining and verifying accurate and reliable flood insurance rate information when purchasing or renewing a flood insurance policy.

text.#text: The

For purposes of this subtitle, the following
		  definitions shall apply:

The term business entity means a corporation,
		  association, partnership, limited liability company, limited liability
		  partnership, or other legal entity.

The term depository institution has the
		  meaning as in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: section 3 of the Federal Deposit Insurance Act
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Federal Deposit Insurance Act/s:3

text.#text:
The term home State means the State in which
		  the insurance producer maintains its principal place of residence or business
		  and is licensed to act as an insurance producer.

The
		  term insurance means any product, other than title insurance or
		  bail bonds, defined or regulated as insurance by the appropriate State
		  insurance regulatory authority.

The term insurance producer means any
		  insurance agent or broker, excess or surplus lines broker or agent, insurance
		  consultant, limited insurance representative, and any other individual or
		  entity that sells, solicits, or negotiates policies of insurance or offers
		  advice, counsel, opinions or services related to insurance.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
section 313(e)(2)(B) of title
		  31, United States Code

text.#text:
The
		  term insurer has the meaning as in

The term principal place of business means
		  the State in which an insurance producer maintains the headquarters of the
		  insurance producer and, in the case of a business entity, where high-level
		  officers of the entity direct, control, and coordinate the business activities
		  of the business entity.

The term principal place of residence
		  means the State in which an insurance producer resides for the greatest number
		  of days during a calendar year.

The
		  term State includes any State, the District of Columbia, any
		  territory of the United States, and Puerto Rico, Guam, American Samoa, the
		  Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands, the Virgin Islands, and the Northern
		  Mariana Islands.

The term State law includes all laws,
		  decisions, rules, regulations, or other State action having the effect of law,
		  of any State.

A law of the United States applicable only
		  to or within the District of Columbia shall be treated as a State law rather
		  than a law of the United
		  States.
